item.title: Different Types of VPN Providers
item.description: You prioritize the privacy of your network, but what happens when you need to connect to the outside world? Do you let anyone and everyone in, or do you secure your network across the distance using a private or virtually private network? Before Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), there were private networks, and they still exist. Some situations demand such high security that the only way to guarantee control and prevent intrusions is through dedicated, point-to-point private lines.

item.title: Advantage of Dedicated Cloud Connections
item.description: Companies of all sizes are increasingly adopting cloud services due to their cost-effectiveness. However, the assumption that a basic internet connection is sufficient for accessing these services is proving to be inaccurate in many situations. While the internet’s widespread availability and affordability make it appealing for WAN services, its security concerns led to the development of VPNs. These secure tunnels encrypt data, allowing remote workers and branch offices to connect securely to corporate networks and transfer sensitive information.

item.title: You Need a Black Cloud Software Defined Perimeter
item.description: By: John Shepler Trust is a liability in today’s digital landscape. The internet, despite its merits, harbors a range of malicious actors, from professional criminals to state-sponsored hackers, all seeking to exploit vulnerabilities. Traditional security measures like firewalls and VPNs may not be enough. Virtual Private Networks: A False Sense of Security? VPNs were designed to emulate the security of private networks over the public internet. They create encrypted “tunnels” for data transmission, shielding it from prying eyes.

item.title: Two Routes to Virtual Private Networking
item.description: VPNs have become the go-to solution for connecting multiple business locations due to their cost-effectiveness and ease of maintenance. Managed service providers allow businesses to enjoy secure multipoint communication without the burden of extensive staffing or high monthly line lease fees. Virtual private networking is now cloud-based, but the choice of cloud type remains. You can opt for a VPN solution using the public internet or choose a completely private network for enhanced performance.

item.title: Virtual Private Network Definition
item.description: While everyone understands the concept of a network, the meaning of a virtual private network (VPN) can be a bit unclear. Essentially, a VPN is a real network that utilizes technology to make its privacy seem virtual. For instance, the internet is inherently public, but methods exist to enhance the privacy of online communications, making them “virtually” private. A genuinely private network necessitates stringent access control. Only authorized individuals and devices should be granted access.

item.title: Transparent LAN Service for WAN Bandwidth
item.description: With the increasing trend of businesses expanding beyond a single location, the demand for reliable wide-area connectivity is on the rise. This is particularly relevant for companies with branches across the country and medical facilities spread over large regions. While traditional telecommunications services have connected multiple locations, newer solutions now allow your local area network (LAN) to cover an entire metropolitan area or even span multiple states. One such solution is known as transparent LAN service, which effectively combines multiple separate LANs into a single, unified network.
